unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about different types of banking and financial identifiers. It's a pretty common question, especially with all the online transactions happening these days. You'll come across terms like IFSC, MICR, and SWIFT codes all the time. It can be confusing.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about different types of banking and financial identifiers. It's a pretty common question, especially with all the online transactions happening these days. You'll come across terms like I-F-S-C, M-I-C-R, and S-W-I-F-T codes all the time. It can be confusing.

unnormalised: First, IFSC stands for Indian Financial System Code. It's an 11-character alphanumeric code, e.g., SBIN0001234, that uniquely identifies a bank branch in India. It's crucial for online fund transfers like NEFT, RTGS, and IMPS. Then there's MICR, which is Magnetic Ink Character Recognition code. It's a 9-digit code found on cheques. The first 3 digits usually represent the city code, the next 3 represent the bank code, and the last 3 the branch code. You might see something like 400006001 on a cheque in Mumbai.
normalised: First, I-F-S-C stands for Indian Financial System Code. It's an eleven character alphanumeric code, for example, S-B-I-N zero zero zero one two three four, that uniquely identifies a bank branch in India. It's crucial for online fund transfers like N-E-F-T, R-T-G-S, and I-M-P-S. Then there's M-I-C-R, which is Magnetic Ink Character Recognition code. It's a nine digit code found on cheques. The first three digits usually represent the city code, the next three represent the bank code, and the last three the branch code. You might see something like four hundred thousand six hundred one on a cheque in Mumbai.

unnormalised: Finally, SWIFT (or BIC) is the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication code. It's used for international money transfers. It's typically an 8 or 11-character code; for example, a SWIFT code might look like CHASUS33 or BKIDINBBXXX. Remember these codes are there to help ensure that money gets to the right place! Think of them like addresses for bank accounts.
normalised: Finally, S-W-I-F-T (or B-I-C) is the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication code. It's used for international money transfers. It's typically an eight or eleven character code; for example, a S-W-I-F-T code might look like C-H-A-S-U-S-three-three or B-K-I-D-I-N-B-B-X-X-X. Remember these codes are there to help ensure that money gets to the right place! Think of them like addresses for bank accounts.
